"Cataract is commonly seen in people above 40 years."
"Children may also develop a cataract."
"People with diabetes or those taking high doses of steroid medications are also at high risk "
What are the symptoms of the cataract?
"●\tBlurring of vision. "
"If left untreated, the patient may turn blind gradually. "
"Other possible symptoms are the presence of bight circles around light, glare, difficulty in the night driving, light seem too dim for reading. "
"What is the treatment for Cataract surgery? "
"The only treatment for cataract is surgery. "
"In early stages vision may improve with glasses."
"In cataract surgery, eye surgeons will remove the cloudy lens and place an artificial lens in the exact position of the original lens. "
"Cataract surgeries are simple, quick, painless, and suture less procedures. "
"The patient can go for surgery when cataract starts affecting their lifestyle. "
"Myopia or Near-sightedness- In myopia, there will be difficulty in seeing distant objects. Myopia is usually inherited. "
"Hyperopia or Long Sightedness- In hyperopia there will be difficulty in seeing near objects. "
"Astigmatism results in distorted vision due to an irregularly curved cornea. (the clear structure covering the eyeball). "
"Presbyopia is linked to aging and can result in blurring of near vision "
What are the symptoms?
"Blurring of vision. "
"Headache /watering/eye-strain while doing near work/studying/watching TV . "
"Children find difficulty in reading from the blackboard when sitting in the backbenches. "
"Children tend to watch TV from a close distance. "
"Squeezing/frequent blinking of the eyes while watching the distant objects. "
What are the symptoms of presbyopia?
"Difficulty in reading, doing computer work, or reading numbers on the mobile phone."
"Difficulty in threading the needle/stitching. "
"Difficulty in cleaning pulses/rice etc. "
What is the available treatment?
"The need for refractive error correction depends on the patient's symptoms, age, and visual needs."
"Asymptomatic patients with low refractive errors may not require correction, "
"Correction options include spectacles, contact lenses, or surgery. "
"Glaucoma causes loss of vision by damaging the part of the eye called the optic nerve. "
"Optic nerves carry information from your eyes to the brain. "
"Glaucoma occurs due to build-up of fluid within the front chamber of the eye (anterior chamber) "
"This increases pressure inside the eye, causing damage to the optic nerve. "
"People with glaucoma usually do not show any symptoms initially. "
"As glaucoma worsens side vision will get reduced and eventually central vision will also get affected. "
"Patients may experience headaches and pain in the eye, the coloured halo around light, nausea, frequent change of spectacle. "

"Anyone can get glaucoma, but some people have higher chances of getting glaucoma. 
●	People above 40 years 
●	Family history of glaucoma 
●	Near-sightedness 
●	Diabetes and hypertension 
●	Long term steroid use "
"There is no permanent cure for glaucoma . "
"Glaucoma can be prevented from getting worse by medication or surgery. "
"Identifying it early is key to protecting your vision. "
It is an eye condition commonly seen in people 50 years and above.
It damages central vision and causes difficulty in reading and driving

"●	Age 50 years and above 

●	Cigarette smoking 

●	Family history of AMD 

●	High cholesterol 

●	Heart disease 

●	Overweight 

●	High blood pressure "
How is it treated?
Currently, no treatment exists for early ARMD
Advise patients to get a comprehensive eye check-up at least once a year and to maintain a healthy lifestyle.
For late cases, high-dose vitamins and minerals are advised
The retina is the tissue layer located in the back of your eye.
Prolonged increase in blood pressure can cause damage to your retina.
When your blood pressure is too high, the retina’s blood vessel walls may thicken.
This may cause your blood vessels to become narrow, which then restricts blood from reaching the retina.
Over time, high blood pressure can cause damage to the retina’s blood vessels, limit the retina’s function, and put pressure on the optic nerve, causing vision problems.
This condition is called hypertensive retinopathy.
Symptoms usually do not develop until late in the disease and include blurred vision.
It can be diagnosed by through a detailed examination of your retina.
Also hypertension combined with diabetes greatly increases the risk of visual loss.
Hypertensive retinopathy is managed primarily by controlling hypertension.
Sometimes laser or injection of corticosteroids is used
Diabetes is a condition in which glucose level in the blood is higher than normal.
A hormone called insulin in your body helps cells to take glucose for energy.
In diabetes, the body will be either unable to produce sufficient insulin or may be unable to utilize insulin well.
This causes glucose to stay in the blood and causes damage
Diabetes can result in diabetic retinopathy.
In diabetic retinopathy, small blood vessels leak and bleed the retina and can cause blindness
What are the symptoms of diabetes?

"You will usually not experience symptoms in the early stages. 

●	A sudden increase in black spots 

●	Blurred vision 

●	Sudden loss of vision in one eye 

●	Bright circles around light 

●	Flashing light "
How can you diagnose diabetic retinopathy?
All people with diabetes must get dilated eye exams at regular intervals to find out the development of any signs of retinopathy, even if their blood sugar is under control.
Is diabetic retinopathy treatable?
In the early stages of diabetic retinopathy control of blood glucose level and an annual or more often dilated eye examination are recommended.
In late stages, treatment options include - medication, lasers, and surgery "
How to control blood sugar levels?
Regular exercise, following a healthy meal plan

"●	Constant eye rubbing 
●	Extreme sensitivity to light 
●	Chronic redness 
●	Chronic watering from eyes 
●	Poor focusing 
●	White instead of a black pupil 
●	Trouble in following objects with eyes 
●	Abnormal alignment of eyes "

"a.	Refractive error 
b.	Corneal scarring mainly from Vitamin A deficiency and measles 
c.	Cataract 
d.	Retinopathy of prematurity 
e.	Refractive error (mostly myopia) 
f. 	Low vision. "
Refractive error occurs when the eyes fail to focus light coming from the object.
Myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism are the type of refractive error seen in young children.
Symptoms of refractive error can include blurry vision, difficulty seeing up close, squinting, and headaches
In amblyopia vision in one of the eyes is reduced because the eye and the brain are not working together properly.
It failed to correct the refractive error in children, it results in amblyopia or lazy eye
"Cataracts are a cloudiness that occurs in the lens of the eye "
In children, abnormal lens development during pregnancy may result in congenital cataracts.
Genetic disorders, infections, and trauma can cause cataracts.
Common symptoms are the presence of white or yellow “glow” in the pupil in flash photos, lack of reaction to light, rapid eye movement, reduced vision
"If the congenital cataract is not treated timely, it can hinder normal vision development and cause amblyopia "
Congenital cataracts are typically treated by cataract surgery.
The cloudy lens is removed and is replaced either by an artificial lens, or the using contact lenses
Retinopathy of prematurity affects children born prematurely.
Mild forms of retinopathy of prematurely usually resolve by itself but severe forms can result in blindness, if not treated
Screening of premature babies for retinopathy of prematurity and timely treatment is very important.
Severe cases of ROP may require surgical treatments.
Preterm children, and those who develop hypoxia, infection, or breathlessness after birth need to be examined within 30 days of birth.
"Squints usually develop during early childhood. "
The eyes of the child will be abnormally aligned.
The eye appears to cross or one wanders to one side.
"Squint is best corrected if noticed during early childhood "
If the squint is not corrected, the brain will ignore the weaker eye
Yes
No

"●	Redness 
●	Eye pain 
●	Sensitivity to light 
●	Blurring of vision 
●	Watering "

"a.	Ocular injuries 
b.	Corneal ulceration 
c.	Trachoma 
d.	Vitamin A deficiency "
Chemical burns and splashes into the eye
Getting sand, dust or other foreign bodies in your eyes
Getting scratches on the eye
Don’t let children play dangerous games like Gulli-danda, bows, and arrows.
Always use proper personal protective equipment recommended at work.
Items of daily use like sharp edged toys, knives, needles, scissors, etc., should be kept away from children.
Avoid the use of chemicals while playing Holi.
Don’t stand too close to firecrackers, adult supervision is essential, while children are playing with crackers.
Wash your eyes immediately in case of the chemical splash of something fell in your eyes
Go to an eye doctor or casuality immediately
Avoid rubbing of your eyes
A corneal ulcer is an open sore present on the cornea. If left untreated can result in corneal blindness

"●	Redness and pain 
●	Foreign body sensation in your eyes 
●	Watering of eyes 
●	Sensitivity to light 
●	Blurring of vision "
It is commonly caused by infections (bacterial, viral, parasitic, fungal), injury to the cornea, dry eye
Most of the causes of corneal ulceration are preventable.
Contact lens wearers
People with corneal injuries or burn
people who use steroid eye drops
people with eyelid disorders that prevent proper functioning of the eyelid
Don\'t let your children play with sharp objects, firecrackers, etc.
"Always use correct protective eyewear at work "
If you are contact lens wearer safe handling, cleaning and storage of contact lens is important
Trachoma is one of the preventable causes of blindness. It is an infectious disease affecting your cornea and conjunctiva.
The infection spreads through personal contact (via hands, clothes or bedding) and by flies that have been in contact with discharge from the eyes or nose of an infected person.
permanent damage to the cornea
Pain and discomfort
Turning inward of eyelashes
"Wash your eyes and face several times with clean water. "
Keep your towel and handkerchief separate from others.
Do not let house flies breed both within the house and in the surrounding.
Maintain personal hygiene and environmental cleanliness.
Treatment of trachoma is possible. Put the eye ointment given by your doctor. Wash your eyes several times with clean water. Inturned eyelashes can be surgically corrected
Vitamin ‘A’ is an essential nutrient for the eyes. Deficiency of vitamin A occurs due to:
"●\tDeficiency of Vitamin A in the diet. \n●\tSeveral episodes of diarrhoea. \n●\tMeasles and other diseases "
If left untreated, it results in total blindness in children.
The condition is curable at an early stage.
Poor vision in dim light and at night.
The white portion of the eye appears lustreless and dull.
The Infant’s skin and eyes appear dry and wrinkled.

Include vitamin A rich food in your diet (green leafy vegetables, carrot, yellow fruits like papaya, mango, banana, and dairy products- milk, curd, cottage cheese. The non-vegetarian sources are fish, egg, and meat.)
All infants should be breastfed from the very first day of their birth.
Vitamin A prophylaxis should be given to all the children from 9 months to 5 years of age at an interval of 6 months.
Open
Close
Wash and sanitize your hands frequently.
Clean your eyes daily with water to get free of infections.
Don’t touch your eyes with unclean hands.
If it is necessary to itch or rub eyes use a tissue instead of fingers.
Keep your personalized articles like towel, handkerchief, bed linen, etc. separate to prevent transmission of infected eye conditions.
Avoid instilling any substance like ghee, cow milk, Gulab Jal, honey, and homemade remedies in the eyes.
Only use medications prescribed by your doctor.
Discard the eye drops once opened within one month of opening, even if their expiry date is not reached.
Always read in good light conditions, dim light strains the eyes.
Do not see a solar eclipse with naked eyes as it may harm your eyes.
Keep your premises clean.
Avoid smoking.
Maintain a balanced diet.
Exercise regularly.

Include vitamin A rich food in your diet (green leafy vegetables, carrot, yellow fruits like papaya, mango, banana, and dairy products- milk, curd, cottage cheese. The non-vegetarian sources are fish, egg, and meat.)
Always wear or remove your glasses with two hands, this can prevent bending the frame.
Always put your spectacles back in the case after the use.
Never leave your glasses lens-side down on a table.
Do not use dirty and scratched glasses.
Do not share or use others spectacles.
Clean your glasses every day with a soft piece of cloth.
Tilt your head back.
Pull your lower eyelid down to create a “cup” that holds the drops or ointment.
Put in the prescribed amount of medicine and close your eyes to distribute it evenly.
If you have trouble doing this, ask a friend or relative for help.
Start with a fresh bottle of medicine after surgery so germs don’t get transferred.
Instil eye-drops/ointments as advised by your operating surgeon.
Protect eyes from bright sunlight, dust, smoke
Avoid lifting heavyweights.
Wear goggles.
Before cleaning eyes, wash hands with soap and water.
Clean your eyes with clean cotton soaked in boiling water for 10 minutes after cooling
Start wiping from the inner corner and move to the periphery.
Do not press or rub it.
If redness, pain, or sudden loss of vision is observed, the patient should contact the doctor immediately.
Get follow up check-up after one week of the surgery and again after 4-6 weeks for spectacles requirement.
Don’t get soap, shampoo, or other irritants in your eye.
Do wear eye shields at night to protect your eyes during sleep.
Don’t bend over to pick things up; kneel instead.
Hygiene and Eye care
Wash your hands with mild soap and dry your hands using lint-free cloth before handling contact lenses
Avoid the use of oily soaps, lotions or oily cosmetics and hand sanitizer before handling contact lens
Ensure that your lens is moist, clean, clear and free of any nicks or tears before putting in eyes
Remove your lenses immediately and contact your eye care personnel, if you experience eye discomfort, excessive tearing, vision changes, and redness of the eye or other problems
Never wear your lenses beyond the prescribed wear schedule, as serious complications may occur, including loss of vision.
Always store your lens in a clean case and replace it once in a month. Bacteria can grow in dirty contact lens cases.
Keep your computer screen lower to your eye level
Position computer to avoid glare from overhead lamps, windows
Use drapes and curtains
Switch off excessive light in the room
Adjust the display setting of your computer
Blink your eyes frequents
Take frequent breaks
Start using the 20-20-20 rule to reduce eye fatigue. Every 20 minutes, look away from your screen and fix your eyes on something at least 20 feet away for at least 20 seconds.
Computer-related eye care problems can be solved to an extent by making changes in the positioning of your computer, by proper eye care and taking regular breaks.
